quotes.topic_title: Introduction and performance marketing definitions
quotes.text: Hot take, paid is for everyone. If you look at the way each platform is doing, Google, you have to scroll pretty far down to get to an organic listing. Meta, it's almost a pay for play now.
quotes.speaker: Timothy Davis
quotes.context: A contrarian stance that paid growth is now table stakes because major platforms increasingly prioritize paid placements over organic reach.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and performance marketing definitions
quotes.text: Instead of thinking about being on top of the page, and that's like ego marketing, I want to be number one. I want to be there all the time. It's about showing to the right person as often as possible.
quotes.speaker: Timothy Davis
quotes.context: Reframes performance marketing away from vanity positioning toward frequency and targeting—optimize for the right audience seeing you consistently.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and performance marketing definitions
quotes.text: Each platform is different. The user behavior is different. Make sure you're not too hard on yourself if it doesn't work. It's okay to fail because we're either winning or we're learning.
quotes.speaker: Timothy Davis
quotes.context: Practical experimentation guidance: expect platform-specific dynamics and treat failed tests as learning rather than a signal to stop.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and performance marketing definitions
quotes.text: Paid can be a lot of things. It can be online, it can be offline, it can also even be affiliates.
quotes.speaker: Timothy Davis
quotes.context: Clarifies the scope of “paid” so teams align on what channels and tactics are actually included in their paid growth discussions.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and performance marketing definitions
quotes.text: Because when you do say paid, because I'm in the industry, I would just, "Oh, they do Google Search and they do Meta and they do things like that." But if you do offline and you just say paid, we may be talking about things, but missing each other on two ships passing in the night.
quotes.speaker: Timothy Davis
quotes.context: A communication heuristic: always specify what “paid” means in your org to avoid misalignment between online, offline, and affiliate efforts.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Fast-forward to today, 23,000 product teams use purpose-built AI in BuildBetter every day.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A concrete adoption data point that signals product-market fit and scale for an AI workflow tool.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: First, BuildBetter uses custom models to turn unstructured data like product and sales calls, support tickets, internal communications and surveys into structured insights. It's like having a dedicated data science team.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A practical two-step mental model: convert messy qualitative inputs into structured insights to operationalize learning.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Second, BuildBetter runs those structured insights into workflows, like weekly reports about customer issues, context-aware PRDs and user research documents with citations.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Actionable methodology: pipe insights directly into recurring artifacts (reports/PRDs/research) to drive execution, not just analysis.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Yes. So we just launched OneSchema file feeds, which allows you to build an integration with any system in 15 minutes as long as you can export a CSV to an SFTP folder.
quotes.speaker: Christina Gilbert
quotes.context: A specific, repeatable integration approach (CSV-to-SFTP) that drastically reduces time-to-integration for tricky systems like ERPs.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: We have a built-in validation layer that stops any bad data from entering your system and OneSchema will notify your team immediately of any data that looks incorrect.
quotes.speaker: Christina Gilbert
quotes.context: A reliability playbook for integrations: prevent bad data at the boundary and alert instantly to avoid outages and customer trust loss.

quotes.topic_title: Is paid growth for every company?
quotes.text: Hot take. I would say, paid is for everyone.
quotes.speaker: Timothy Davis
quotes.context: A contrarian stance that reframes paid growth as a universal requirement rather than an optional channel.

quotes.topic_title: Is paid growth for every company?
quotes.text: If you look at the way each platform is doing, Google introducing AI, plus with paid taking up the first four spots, you have to scroll pretty far down to get to an organic listing.
quotes.speaker: Timothy Davis
quotes.context: Explains a structural reason paid is increasingly necessary: organic visibility is being pushed down by platform changes.

quotes.topic_title: Is paid growth for every company?
quotes.text: Meta, it's almost a pay for play now. You have to do promoted posts for people to even see your content.
quotes.speaker: Timothy Davis
quotes.context: A practical warning that organic distribution on major social platforms may be insufficient without paid amplification.

quotes.topic_title: Is paid growth for every company?
quotes.text: But I would say at baseline, everyone should be doing paid search.
quotes.speaker: Timothy Davis
quotes.context: Actionable baseline recommendation: start with paid search as the default paid channel.

quotes.topic_title: Is paid growth for every company?
quotes.text: The way I usually explain it to people is paid search is user driven. You have to type in a relevant keyword for your ad to show.
quotes.speaker: Timothy Davis
quotes.context: A simple mental model for channel selection: prioritize intent-driven paid search versus more interruptive formats.

quotes.topic_title: When paid can be the primary growth engine
quotes.text: I always say, where are your users?
quotes.speaker: Timothy Davis
quotes.context: A simple diagnostic framework for deciding whether paid can become a primary growth engine: start by identifying where users already are.

quotes.topic_title: When paid can be the primary growth engine
quotes.text: But always look at the data that's available to you within your analytics platforms and say, "Users are already finding us here. How can we turn that knob up to 11?" And you can do that with paid.
quotes.speaker: Timothy Davis
quotes.context: Actionable method: use existing channel attribution in analytics to pick paid channels where demand already exists and scale them.

quotes.topic_title: When paid can be the primary growth engine
quotes.text: So there was a company I worked with a couple of years ago called, Hairstory and IPSY. I know, very funny. Guy with no hair working on a company called Hairstory, but they were doing really well from a Google shopping standpoint. But when I started consulting with them, we looked at the analytics and we actually saw that they were getting a lot of people from Meta and TikTok at the time.
quotes.speaker: Timothy Davis
quotes.context: Concrete example of using analytics to uncover underappreciated acquisition channels beyond the obvious (Google Shopping).

quotes.topic_title: When paid can be the primary growth engine
quotes.text: So you can't always just take what is currently working on one platform and apply it to another because it is a different user experience. It is a different mindset that the user has when they're on there.
quotes.speaker: Timothy Davis
quotes.context: Counterintuitive creative lesson: cross-posting “winning” ads across platforms often fails due to different user intent and context.

quotes.topic_title: Running “signs of life” tests on channels
quotes.text: You can always do a very, very small test. You can just put a little money into a platform, see if there's a sign of life. If there is, then you can pull back and say, "Okay, we have signs of life. Now let's build a campaign around that."
quotes.speaker: Timothy Davis
quotes.context: Introduces the “signs of life” methodology: validate a channel with a tiny spend before investing in full campaign build-out.

quotes.topic_title: Running “signs of life” tests on channels
quotes.text: There's no reason to say, "All right, we have a signs of life. Let's now turn it up all the way." Do we have the right creative? Do we have the right campaign? Do we have the right messaging for the users on this platform?
quotes.speaker: Timothy Davis
quotes.context: Warns against prematurely scaling after early signal; emphasizes readiness checks (creative, campaign, messaging) before ramping spend.

quotes.topic_title: Running “signs of life” tests on channels
quotes.text: The number one thing I tell people all the time is use your own data, start with your own data. So take the existing customer base you have, load that up into the platform to build lookalikes.
quotes.speaker: Timothy Davis
quotes.context: Gives a concrete starting tactic for experiments: seed targeting with first-party customer data to improve early test signal.

quotes.topic_title: Running “signs of life” tests on channels
quotes.text: What I tend to do is build ad sets, one at 1% because we know that one's going to be highly correlated to what we're looking for. Then a two to four, and then a five to seven, and then an eight plus. More times than not, the eight plus does not work, but there have been times where it has, so it's, "Hey, let's do it. Let's try it."
quotes.speaker: Timothy Davis
quotes.context: Provides a practical testing structure for lookalikes (1%, 2–4, 5–7, 8+) plus an empirical note that broad audiences often fail but can occasionally win.

quotes.topic_title: Running “signs of life” tests on channels
quotes.text: But if you also have a very limited budget because some people don't have the luxury of having an unlimited budget like we do in some of these other companies I've worked at, just start with the 1%. See what that sign of life is because you already know that this is so tied to your existing customer base.
quotes.speaker: Timothy Davis
quotes.context: Offers budget-sensitive guidance: begin with the tightest lookalike (1%) to maximize signal quality when spend is constrained.

quotes.topic_title: Diagnosing failures: targeting, creative, and measurement
quotes.text: Click-through rate basically just tells you, are the users engaged? Because start with the target. You're getting the impressions are there. Is the target right? That should be your first thing. Yes, the target is correct. Users that we want to see are seeing our ads, but they're not engaging with it. That would be the first thing.
quotes.speaker: Timothy Davis
quotes.context: A practical diagnostic sequence: validate targeting via impressions/reach first, then use CTR as an engagement signal to isolate creative issues.

quotes.topic_title: Diagnosing failures: targeting, creative, and measurement
quotes.text: That's where honestly, the only way you're going to get an answer to that outside of the data that's available to you like click-through rate, reach, frequency and all those things to pull in more metrics, is a focus group to understand, "Hey, when you saw this image with this content, what was your result from it?"
quotes.speaker: Timothy Davis
quotes.context: Highlights the limits of platform metrics and recommends qualitative research (focus groups) to uncover why creative/content isn’t resonating.

quotes.topic_title: Diagnosing failures: targeting, creative, and measurement
quotes.text: Now, you can build a test within the platform to do a control versus a test where say, you take the creative with the same primary and the same description versus a creative that's just your logo with the headline and the description and see what the results are.
quotes.speaker: Timothy Davis
quotes.context: Gives a concrete control-vs-test methodology to isolate the impact of the visual creative while holding copy constant.

quotes.topic_title: Diagnosing failures: targeting, creative, and measurement
quotes.text: But more times than not, you're not getting the understanding from the user of, well, why doesn't that creative resonate with you? And they'll give you suggestions in the focus group.
quotes.speaker: Timothy Davis
quotes.context: Emphasizes that performance data often can’t explain “why,” and that user dialogue can generate actionable creative improvements.

quotes.topic_title: Test duration, budget constraints, and projections
quotes.text: Ideally, in a perfect world, you're going to hear the word, statistical relevance.
quotes.speaker: Timothy Davis
quotes.context: Sets the ideal benchmark for test duration: run tests long enough to reach statistical relevance.

quotes.topic_title: Test duration, budget constraints, and projections
quotes.text: And I'm not going to pretend like a mathematician, but a lot of times, it's budget constraint.
quotes.speaker: Timothy Davis
quotes.context: Highlights the practical reality that test length is often dictated by budget rather than perfect statistical rigor.

quotes.topic_title: Test duration, budget constraints, and projections
quotes.text: So there could be a VP finance. Anyone like that could just come to you and just say, "Hey, do you have $25,000 for this test?" You only have 5,000. Just get that information, get that data.
quotes.speaker: Timothy Davis
quotes.context: Gives a concrete example of budget constraints and the advice to still run a smaller test to gather directional data.

quotes.topic_title: Test duration, budget constraints, and projections
quotes.text: We put $1,000 behind this test. We know that our impression share was this, our reach was this. If we were to put $10,000 into it, this is the expected return we can get from it based on the click-through rate, the conversion rate that we got from the test that we ran.
quotes.speaker: Timothy Davis
quotes.context: Provides a scalable methodology: use small-test metrics (CTR/CVR, reach, impression share) to project returns at higher spend.

quotes.topic_title: Experimentation mindset and platform differences
quotes.text: Make sure you're not too hard on yourself if it doesn't work.
quotes.speaker: Timothy Davis
quotes.context: Encourages teams to normalize early failure in platform experiments so they keep iterating instead of quitting.

quotes.topic_title: Experimentation mindset and platform differences
quotes.text: I believe in creating an environment where it's okay to fail because we're either winning or we're learning.
quotes.speaker: Timothy Davis
quotes.context: A simple experimentation culture framework that reframes outcomes as either success or learning.

quotes.topic_title: Experimentation mindset and platform differences
quotes.text: Just know there's going to be things you're not going to understand because each platform is unique, each platform is different, the user behavior is different.
quotes.speaker: Timothy Davis
quotes.context: Highlights why tactics don’t transfer cleanly across channels and why platform-specific learning is required.

quotes.topic_title: Experimentation mindset and platform differences
quotes.text: So give yourself some grace, understand that this may not work. And as long as you're learning from it, you're going to be okay.
quotes.speaker: Timothy Davis
quotes.context: Reinforces an iterative mindset: experiments can “fail” as long as they produce learning you can apply next cycle.

quotes.topic_title: Which platforms to prioritize and why
quotes.text: But if you're just starting out and you just want to get your feet wet into something, I would say start with Google Search, then get into Meta. And if you have video available, definitely get into YouTube.
quotes.speaker: Timothy Davis
quotes.context: A clear prioritization sequence practitioners can follow when choosing initial paid channels based on readiness and creative capabilities.

quotes.topic_title: Which platforms to prioritize and why
quotes.text: And as long as you can get that creative and get it consistently just because you have one piece of creative, if it's doing well, you do need to have that creative refresh, kind of that flywheel going.
quotes.speaker: Timothy Davis
quotes.context: Highlights the operational requirement (a creative refresh flywheel) to make video channels work sustainably, not just a one-off win.

quotes.topic_title: Which platforms to prioritize and why
quotes.text: LinkedIn is very expensive in comparison. So just know if you're going into LinkedIn, it's going to look almost three times more expensive than other channels.
quotes.speaker: Timothy Davis
quotes.context: A concrete cost expectation that helps teams set realistic CAC benchmarks and avoid misreading early LinkedIn performance.

quotes.topic_title: Which platforms to prioritize and why
quotes.text: The targeting that's available on LinkedIn, knowing job titles, industries, actually targeting people at certain companies is very powerful.
quotes.speaker: Timothy Davis
quotes.context: Explains the core reason to pay LinkedIn’s premium—precision targeting that can justify higher costs for the right use cases.

quotes.topic_title: Which platforms to prioritize and why
quotes.text: I would not recommend getting into LinkedIn until you've tested Google and Meta first.
quotes.speaker: Timothy Davis
quotes.context: Counter to the common B2B instinct to start on LinkedIn, this suggests validating demand and creative fit on cheaper channels first.

quotes.topic_title: What makes YouTube video ads work
quotes.text: Yeah. You got to make sure you have that flywheel.
quotes.speaker: Timothy Davis
quotes.context: Emphasizes that scalable YouTube performance depends on having a repeatable system to continuously produce video ads.

quotes.topic_title: What makes YouTube video ads work
quotes.text: So yeah. The thing with YouTube is I always say, start with emotion.
quotes.speaker: Timothy Davis
quotes.context: A clear creative principle for YouTube ads: lead with emotional impact rather than product details.

quotes.topic_title: What makes YouTube video ads work
quotes.text: If you can have an emotional connection with the user, is going to be way more impactful and way more powerful than anything else.
quotes.speaker: Timothy Davis
quotes.context: Prioritizes emotional resonance as the primary driver of ad effectiveness on YouTube.

quotes.topic_title: What makes YouTube video ads work
quotes.text: It is just making sure the user feels something after seeing your ad.
quotes.speaker: Timothy Davis
quotes.context: Turns “emotion” into an actionable creative bar: the ad must reliably produce a feeling.

quotes.topic_title: What makes YouTube video ads work
quotes.text: Because then, they're more times not going to remember it, which then they will take a favorable action after the fact.
quotes.speaker: Timothy Davis
quotes.context: Connects emotion to a downstream mechanism—memorability leading to later conversion behavior.

quotes.topic_title: Emerging channels: podcasts, CTV, VR, AI ads
quotes.text: When you say emerging channels, my brain kind of goes to connected TV, podcast, VR, advertising, audio/voice search, and even AI stuff right now.
quotes.speaker: Timothy Davis
quotes.context: A concise scan of emerging paid channels to consider beyond the usual core platforms.

quotes.topic_title: Emerging channels: podcasts, CTV, VR, AI ads
quotes.text: I can tell you podcasts are doing really well for the people that I know are able to measure it correctly.
quotes.speaker: Timothy Davis
quotes.context: Highlights measurement as the key gating factor for making podcast ads work.

quotes.topic_title: Emerging channels: podcasts, CTV, VR, AI ads
quotes.text: Connected TV is also doing really well. You can take the, again, you're doing YouTube right now, being able to take that creative and repurpose it.
quotes.speaker: Timothy Davis
quotes.context: Actionable tactic: repurpose existing YouTube creative to test CTV efficiently.

quotes.topic_title: Emerging channels: podcasts, CTV, VR, AI ads
quotes.text: I kind of like letting other people be the guinea pig and learning from them, and then if someone comes to me and they're like, "Hey, we have budget for this, let's go ahead and test it." "Great. Let's go. Let's see what we can learn."
quotes.speaker: Timothy Davis
quotes.context: A pragmatic risk-management approach to emerging channels: learn from others first, then run funded tests to capture learnings.

quotes.topic_title: When to start paid and scaling considerations
quotes.text: If you're looking for something quick, paid needs to start immediate. And paid [inaudible 00:28:24] started yesterday because SEO takes time.
quotes.speaker: Timothy Davis
quotes.context: A clear timing heuristic: use paid for speed and recognize SEO’s inherent lag.

quotes.topic_title: When to start paid and scaling considerations
quotes.text: You don't want to build awareness through search. You build awareness through display media-based type media.
quotes.speaker: Timothy Davis
quotes.context: A channel-to-objective rule of thumb that challenges the common instinct to use search for awareness.

quotes.topic_title: When to start paid and scaling considerations
quotes.text: So, it depends on what is the demand of your product and market.
quotes.speaker: Timothy Davis
quotes.context: A simple decision framework: choose paid approach based on existing demand vs. needing to create it.

quotes.topic_title: When to start paid and scaling considerations
quotes.text: We can go out there and just start bidding on monday.com and say, "See why Lenny and Tim are better than monday.com."
quotes.speaker: Timothy Davis
quotes.context: A concrete example of demand-capture via competitor bidding (“coattail riding”) to drive early trials.

quotes.topic_title: When to start paid and scaling considerations
quotes.text: So, it just really depends on, A, when do you expect results because SEO can take time. And B, what is the demand in the market for your product?
quotes.speaker: Timothy Davis
quotes.context: A two-factor checklist for when to start/scale paid: speed requirements and market demand.

quotes.topic_title: Paid before product-market fit risks
quotes.text: the biggest issue wasn't necessarily that users weren't interested in our product and weren't purchasing it, it was because we didn't have a product market fit mainly from an operation standpoint.
quotes.speaker: Timothy Davis
quotes.context: Reframes PMF as not just demand/product, but operational readiness to serve and convert customers in a market.

quotes.topic_title: Paid before product-market fit risks
quotes.text: In Africa, there are multitudes of different types of currency. There's the franc, there's the rand, there's the shill, and we were just, "Hey, USD, thank you."
quotes.speaker: Timothy Davis
quotes.context: Concrete example of how a seemingly small operational constraint (payments/currency) can kill conversion despite demand.

quotes.topic_title: Paid before product-market fit risks
quotes.text: All you're going to do is really annoy the users.
quotes.speaker: Timothy Davis
quotes.context: Warns that paid spend pre-conversion-readiness can create negative brand impressions, not just wasted budget.

quotes.topic_title: Paid before product-market fit risks
quotes.text: From an operation standpoint, I always want to make sure those things are tied off.
quotes.speaker: Timothy Davis
quotes.context: Actionable guidance: ensure operational blockers are resolved before scaling paid acquisition.

quotes.topic_title: Paid before product-market fit risks
quotes.text: But just know that it's probably not going to convert very well.
quotes.speaker: Timothy Davis
quotes.context: Sets expectations that awareness spend without conversion readiness will underperform, helping practitioners decide when to invest.

quotes.topic_title: Why agencies underperform and how to use them
quotes.text: But I think a lot of agencies just come in and they go, "Oh, this is like AB&C company. And this is what we're doing. Copy, paste, done, move on."
quotes.speaker: Timothy Davis
quotes.context: A crisp diagnosis of why many agencies underperform: they apply generic playbooks instead of account-specific strategy.

quotes.topic_title: Why agencies underperform and how to use them
quotes.text: For example, I have ops cadence that myself and my team follow. So, within that ops cadence, we have things like finance, performance, structure, keywords, ad copy, quality score, targeting, et cetera, et cetera.
quotes.speaker: Timothy Davis
quotes.context: Introduces an operational cadence framework for systematically managing performance marketing beyond just campaign tweaks.

quotes.topic_title: Why agencies underperform and how to use them
quotes.text: Well, what about looking at your conversions? Where are we converting? Have we tested different landing pages? What is a better user experience that we could be getting users right now? It's a five-step process, can we get it to a three?
quotes.speaker: Timothy Davis
quotes.context: Actionable reminder that growth often comes from conversion/UX and landing page work—not only in-platform optimizations.

quotes.topic_title: Why agencies underperform and how to use them
quotes.text: So let's create milestones along the way of making sure we're checking in and saying, when is the right time to hire? Whether that's a data scientist, whether that's a creative person in-house or replacing me full time.
quotes.speaker: Timothy Davis
quotes.context: A practical planning model: use agencies to start, but set explicit hiring milestones to avoid being bottlenecked by external partners.

quotes.topic_title: Why agencies underperform and how to use them
quotes.text: Create that milestone of, "Hey, when we're spending 50K a month, I need to hire somebody full time to take this over." And just have that conversation with your agency and your consultant. I think more times than not, you will have a positive reaction to that. But if you don't, I would say that's a major red flag and probably someone you shouldn't be partnering with.
quotes.speaker: Timothy Davis
quotes.context: A concrete threshold + red-flag test you can apply immediately when evaluating whether an agency is aligned with your long-term success.

quotes.topic_title: First in-house hire: signal vs noise mindset
quotes.text: Because I can teach anyone how to do Google ads. I can teach anyone how to do Meta ads. That is not the hard part. It is the data part that is the hard part because there is so much noise going on in those accounts.
quotes.speaker: Timothy Davis
quotes.context: A hiring heuristic: prioritize analytical thinking and signal-detection over channel-specific execution skills.

quotes.topic_title: First in-house hire: signal vs noise mindset
quotes.text: Hold on, that's a lot of noise you just said. So what is the signal and what is the noise? And let's make sure we're focusing on the right signal versus the right noise.
quotes.speaker: Timothy Davis
quotes.context: A practical mental model for navigating metric overload in ad platforms by explicitly separating decision-driving metrics from distractions.

quotes.topic_title: First in-house hire: signal vs noise mindset
quotes.text: And one of the interview questions I usually ask is I throw a bunch of data points at them and then say, "Out of all that, what would you do to optimize the account?"
quotes.speaker: Timothy Davis
quotes.context: A concrete interview tactic to test prioritization and judgment under real-world data overload.

quotes.topic_title: First in-house hire: signal vs noise mindset
quotes.text: But the people that I like are like, " Well, what's the purpose of the campaign?"
quotes.speaker: Timothy Davis
quotes.context: A simple litmus test for strong candidates: they anchor metric selection to the campaign objective before optimizing anything.

quotes.topic_title: First in-house hire: signal vs noise mindset
quotes.text: Because who cares about how many impressions you're getting? Who cares about the reach? Who cares about the frequency? If the goal of the campaign is to get the conversions, that's what we should be doing.
quotes.speaker: Timothy Davis
quotes.context: A contrarian reminder to ignore popular top-of-funnel metrics when they don’t match the campaign goal, and optimize to the outcome instead.
